Project Description  Under the Five-Year Plan (NFYP, 2002-2007), the Government of 
Bhutan (the Government) intends to electrify 15,000 households. 
Under the project, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) will assist 
the Government to electrify about 8,000 rural consumers, mostly 
households,  but  including  hospitals,  schools,  and  other  public 
facilities  for  local  communities.  The  8,000  consumers  were 
selected based on social and technical criteria to ensure that 43% 
of the households connected are below the poverty line.  Based 
on  this  criteria,  eight  districts  were  selected  for  the  Project: 
Chhukha,  Lhuentse,  Mongar,  Pemagatshel,  Punakha,  Samtse, 
Sarpang,  and  Trashigang.    The  Government  expects  to  get 
financial assistance from the Government of the Netherlands and 
the Government of Austria to finance the electrification of 4,000 
households.    The  Government  is  expected  to  make  funds 
available to finance the remaining 3,000 households.  The Project 
will (i) construct 390 circuit kilometers (cct-km) of 33 kilo-volt (kV) 
overhead lines; (ii) construct 300 cct-km of 11 kV overhead lines; 
(iii)  install  160  33/0.4  kV  and  170  11/0.4  kV  distribution 
transformers with associated drop-out fuse assemblies and low 
voltage (LV) boards; (iv) install 570 cct-km of LV aerial bundled 
conductors;  and  (v)  installation  of  service  cables  and  energy 
meters to 8,000 customers.  The Government and ADB are also 
engaged in a long-term policy dialogue to restructure the power 
sector in order to improve sector efficiency. As a result of this 
dialogue,  the  former  Department  of  Power  was  unbundled 
creating the Department of Energy (DOE) as the governmental 
planning agency, Bhutan Electricity Authority (BEA) as the sector 
regulator, and BPC as the a transmission, distribution and supply 
corporation.  Two  technical  assistance  (TA)  projects  are  piggy-
backed  to  the  Project  and  represent  the  next  step  in  sector 
restructuring. 
   
Rationale  Although Bhutan has substantial sources of clean and renewable 
indigenous  hydropower  energy,  the  distribution  of  electricity 
throughout  the  country  is  still  limited.    According  to  the  most 
recent estimates, the population of Bhutan is about 695,000, of 
whom 80% reside in rural areas. About 66,000 of the 85,000 rural 
households are without electricity. The Project will bring additional 
social and economic benefits including improved living standards 
and conditions for education and health service delivery; and

ii  
  improved opportunities for the rural and urban poor to increase 
their  economic  productivity,  create  employment  and  raise 
household income. In addition, the Government’s policy for rural 
electrification  is  to  reduce  fuelwood  consumption  by  using 
electricity for lighting as well as for cooking.  The annual per 
capita consumption of fuelwood is at 1.22 tons, one of the highest 
in the world.  Between 45% and 71% of rural households reported 
they have increased difficulty in collecting fuelwood due to much 
diminished forest cover compared with ten years ago. 
   
Objectives  The objectives are to: (i) expand the delivery of electricity from 
existing  national  hydropower  stations  as  an  important  and 
necessary input for rural residents in Bhutan to improve their living 
standards, conditions for education, and health service delivery; 
and (ii) provide opportunities for the rural poor to increase their 
economic productivity, create jobs and raise income.

Project Benefits and  The Project will increase the national electrification rate by 8%, 
Beneficiaries  from the current 35% to about 43%. About 43% of the households 
to be electrified are now below the national poverty line of about 
$187 per capita per year.  The project has established criteria for 
providing electrification kits to the poorest households in order to 
address  the  issue  of  affordability.    The  Project  will  improve 
standards  of  living  for  these  households  through  the  use  of 
electric  lighting  and  other  appliances.    Electrification  has 
generated  additional  income-generating  opportunities  through 
several means: establishment of small-scale cottage industries, 
engaging in mini-food processing, increasing efficiency in small 
trades  such  as  carpentry  and  tailoring,  and  establishing  small

due to a cleaner environment without kerosene lamps, with less

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to the Kingdom of Bhutan for the Rural Electrification and Network Expansion Project.  The 
report also describes proposed technical assistance (TA) for (i) Capacity Building of the Bhutan 
Electricity Authority, and (ii) Establishment of the Druk Hydropower Corporation, and if the 
Board approves the proposed loan, I, acting under the authority delegated to me by the Board, 
will approve the two TAs. 
 
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
2.  The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  provided  a  project  preparatory  TA1  with  the 
objective of (i) establishing the technical, economic, financial, and social feasibility of the project; 
and (ii) providing the Department of Energy (DOE) and the Bhutan Power Corporation (BPC) 
with capacity for preparing similar future projects for external financing.  The project framework 
is in Appendix 1. 
 
3.  Most of Bhutan’s power comes from run-of-the-river hydropower from the four major 
rivers: Ammochu, Mangdechhu, Samkosh, and Wangchu. Currently, Bhutan has 26 hydropower 
stations with a total installed capacity of about 445 megawatts (MW) and a maximum demand of 
96  MW.    There  are  currently  three  main  generating  companies:  Chhukha  Hydropower 
Corporation (CHPC, 336 MW, funded by India) and the Baso Chhu (Phase 1) Hydropower 
Corporation  (BHPC,  24  MW,  funded  by  Austria)  in  the  Western  Region  and  Kurichhu 
Hydropower Corporation (KHPC, 60MW, funded by India) in the Eastern Region. All three 
companies are wholly Government-owned.  Although CHPC, KHPC, and BHPC provide most of 
the power capacity, there are eight mini-hydro plants with capacities ranging from 300 kilowatt 
(kW) to 2,200 kW, and 15 microhydro plants with capacities ranging from 8 kW to 200 kW. The 
total installed capacity of microhydro plants has reached about 1,000 kW.  Baso Chhu Phase 2 
will be completed in 2004 (40 MW, funded by Austria) and the Tala Hydropower Project (THPC, 
1,020 MW, funded by India) will be completed by 2006.  The theoretical potential hydropower in 
Bhutan is 30,000 MW.  DOE has conducted prefeasibility and feasibility studies on projects 
totaling 16,280 MW.  Further, the Governments of Norway and Japan have funded full-scale 
technical feasibility studies for the Mangdechhu Hydropower Project (completed in 1999 for 360 
MW) and Punatsangchu Hydropower Project (completed in 2001 for 870 MW). 
 
4.  Hydropower  is  Bhutan’s  most  important  natural  resource.    Because  the  country 
generates significantly more electricity than it consumes, Bhutan is a net power exporter.  In 
FY2001,  power  exports  of  1,380  gigawatt-hours  (77  percent  of  the  energy  the  country 
generated) to India accounted for over 43% of the national revenue.  Almost all this power came 
from CHPC and as such, CHPC is the largest single foreign exchange earner of Bhutan.  Under 
the current power purchase agreement with India, CHPC and KHPC are under no obligation to 
export any fixed amount of capacity or energy to India.  Their first priority is to supply the 
necessary  electricity  to  BPC  for  domestic  consumers.    Only  the  balance  of  the  country’s 
electricity output is to be exported to India.  As such, there is no excess generation capacity.  
Given this situation, the Government has put the highest priority on developing its hydropower

B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
  1.  Nature of Rural Electrification in Bhutan 
 
7.  Given Bhutan’s mountainous terrain and highly dispersed population, the expansion of 
the rural electrification (RE) network system poses additional challenges.  The RE system 
expansion has outpaced the extension of the road network.  As a result, the cost of grid 
extension  and  household  connections  are  high,  currently  averaging  about  $1,400  per 
household.  Costs will increase even further as RE moves to even more remote villages and 
households.  Given this situation, DOE, BPC, and ADB have worked hard on the technical and 
economic  balance  in  the  design  of  the  Project  to  ensure  subprojects  that  are  techno-
economically feasible.  However, for future RE extension, the subprojects will be in even more 
remote areas as the more accessible villages are usually the ones to get electrified first.  This 
will affect the technical as well as economic viability of future grid extension.  Future projects 
may have to weigh the benefits and the costs of grid extension against off-grid applications such 
as micro and minihydro stations with a small grid, community solar photo-voltaic (PV) charging 
stations, or household PV systems. 
 
2.  Capacity Building and Sector Restructuring

Considering the human resource constraints, the Government and ADB agreed to implement a 
series of sequenced TAs that together, would restructure and strengthen the power sector over 
eight years.  The TAs have helped to build the institutional capacity of DOP, established the

3.  Lessons Learned from Previous RE Loans 
 
10.  ADB had provided three project preparatory TAs4 and financed two loans for RE.5  The 
Loan for the Rural Electrification Project was delayed by approximately one year because of 
procurement issues, problems in logistical arrangements related to transportation and storage, 
inexperienced local contractors, and force majeure (heavy rains) in 1998.  However, the project 
was satisfactorily completed in 1999.  The loan for the Sustainable Rural Electrification Project 
also started slowly because of procurement delays, but is now on track to be completed by the 
loan closing date of April 2004.  The loan is projected to electrify about 7,000 households, over 
800 more than the 6,028 that were originally targeted for the project.   
 
11.  The Project will benefit from the lessons learned from the previous two RE projects that 
ADB has financed.6  The general quality of construction in the first two projects is good and all 
installations generally conform to the technical specifications.  The installations should provide a 
reliable electricity supply to BPC’s customers.  The lessons learned from the previous projects 
follow.  (i) Standardization of equipment. The technical design for the RE program under the 9th 
Five-Year Plan (NFYP), including the Project, specifically focused on standardizing the plant 
and materials for BPC.  This will result in efficiencies in procuring plant and materials, operating 
and maintaining the system, training staff, and reduce stores inventories, and therefore, overall

4.  Need for Greater Resource Efficiency 
 
12.  Bhutan generates significantly more power than it consumes and all the excess power 
generated is sold to India.  Revenues from the power sector, representing over 43% of the 
national revenue, help pay for government expenditures in all other sectors.  As such, the power 
sector is the single most important sector in Bhutan and will be the engine for economic growth 
and development.   
 
13.  The Government has also chosen to transfer this wealth from the power sector to its

following  factors:  (i)  service  coverage  is  still  poor  and  about  66,000  of  the  85,000  rural

(ii) the Government’s policy is to decrease greenhouse gas emissions by replacing kerosene for 
lighting and fuel-wood for cooking with electricity; (iii) revenue to be generated from increased

III.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
A.  Objectives 
19.  The proposed loan will fund a poverty intervention project with economic growth as its 
thematic classification.  The objectives are to (i) expand the delivery of electricity from existing 
national hydropower stations as an important and necessary input to rural residents in Bhutan to 
improve their living standards, conditions for education, and health service delivery; and (ii) 
provide the rural poor with opportunities to increase their economic productivity, create and 
obtain jobs, and raise their income.  
 
B.  Components and Outputs 
20.  Under the NFYP, the Government intends to electrify 15,000 households.  ADB provided 
a PPTA to DOE and BPC to undertake the technical design, and financial, economic, social, 
and environmental analyses for electrifying the 15,000 households and other consumers.  Of 
the 15,000 households, the Project will electrify about 8,000 rural consumers and a population 
of about 50,000.  The Project will also electrify hospitals, schools, and other public facilities for 
local communities.  This will correspond to an increase of about 20% in the total number of 
consumers served by BPC, or an 8% increase in the total proportion of the national population 
with electricity supply, from the current 35% to about 43%. The 8,000 consumers were selected

below the poverty line (para. 21).  The project will (i) construct 390 circuit kilometers (cct-km) of 
33 kilo-volt (kV) overhead lines; (ii) construct 300 cct-km of 11 kV overhead lines; (iii) install 160 
33/0.4 kV and 170 11/0.4 kV distribution transformers with associated drop-out fuse assemblies 
and low voltage (LV) boards; (iv) install 570 cct-km of LV aerial bundled conductors; and (v) 
installation of service cables and energy meters to 8,000 customers.   
 
C.  Special Features - Selection of Subprojects and Ensuring Affordability 
21.  For the ongoing Sustainable Rural Electrification Project, the beneficiaries were not 
sufficiently  targeted  during  project  design.    Therefore,  to  meet  the  targeted  number  of

below the poverty line.  The criteria included the project’s poverty intervention criterion (i.e., 43

10%), total costs of connecting each household (not to exceed $1,700) and resettlement and 
environmental considerations.  Further, the Project deemed it more effective to focus on specific

V.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 
A.  Social Aspects 
 
1.  Poverty and Social Issues 
 
40.  The Project will give about 8,000 households access to electricity. About 43% are below 
the national poverty line of $187 per capita per year. The targeted districts have a sufficient 
number  of  poor  and  vulnerable  households  among  the  20  districts.  Social  and  poverty 
information was obtained from primary data collected through the ADB study on Socioeconomic 
Impacts of Rural Electrification (Phase 1 Survey), information from the Household Income and 
Expenditure  Survey  (HEIS),  the  Poverty  Assessment  and  Analysis  Report  2000,  the 
Comprehensive Food Security Programme Report and rapid rural assessment (RRA). The 
project targets eight districts where, according to Phase 1 survey, in six districts 23% of the 
households fall below the poverty line and 69% fall into the category of vulnerable households. 
The remaining two districts have food insecurity and therefore, are well within the vulnerable 
category. The targeting of poor and vulnerable districts for electrification will avoid the problem 
of poverty targeting experienced in previous RE projects.  
 
41.  Focus  group  discussions  and  surveys  based  on  previous  projects  indicate  that 
beneficiaries  report  considerable  value  addition  to  the  quality  of  their  life  as  a  result  of 
electrification. It is expected that in addition to quality of life improvements, electricity will provide 
opportunities  for  households  to  improve  incomes  by  establishing  new  businesses  and/or 
expanding  current  ones.  Electrification  has  generated  additional  income-generating 
opportunities through several means: establishment of small-scale cottage industries, engaging 
in mini-food processing, increasing efficiency in small trades such as carpentry and tailoring, 
and establishing small shops, bars, and restaurants. Households below the poverty line use an 
average 51 kilowatt-hour (kWh) of electricity per month with an average cost of about Nu30. The 
minimum charge by BPC is Nu35. Without electricity, 5 liters of kerosene used for lighting by 
low-income households costs about Nu60 a month. Monthly electricity bills are only half this 
amount.   
 
42.  Women  are  expected  to  benefit  through  additional  lighting,  reduced  time  spent  on 
collecting fuelwood, use of rice cookers that also reduce indoor smoke pollution, and increased 
light  and/or  motive  power  for  home  based  income-generating  activities  such  as  weaving.

Replacing kerosene with electricity will result in a cleaner environment, improved indoor living 
conditions, and better health.   
 
43.  In  addition  to  routine  PPMS,  BPC  will  engage  consultants  to  undertake  benefit 
monitoring and evaluation of social and poverty benefits. An outline of the terms of reference for

44.  The project will not have any adverse impact on indigenous peoples and all ethno-

2.  Land Acquisition and Resettlement 
 
45.  BPC  reviewed  the  technical  design  to  explore  opportunities  for  minimizing  land 
acquisition. Appropriate technical solutions were found. The project will not entail compulsory 
land acquisition, as all transformers will be pole mounted. Angle and distribution poles will be

B.  Financial Aspects 
 
46.  BPC was only recently established  (July 2002) and has not yet produced a full set of 
certified financial statements. BPC will produce its first financial statement for the first 18 months 
of operation on 31 December 2003. However, BPC has developed a five-year financial forecast.  
They are based on BPC estimates of its current financial position; forecast estimates of sales 
growth (number of customers and kWh consumption per customer), increase in tariffs, and 
increase in operations as well as capital expenditure. Based on these assumptions, BPC is 
financially viable in the short term. However, this assumes a low bulk supply price of electricity 
to BPC, and substantial cross-subsidies from HV and MV customers to LV rural and urban 
customers. Moreover, it assumes strong rates of growth: number of customers, kWh sales, 
increase in tariffs, and increase in financed expenditure levels. It will therefore be critical for 
BPC to finalize its corporate strategy and business plan, and prepare and have its FY2003 
financial statements independently certified within 6 months of the end of the fiscal year. BPC’s 
corporate strategy and business plan should be based on the FY2003 financial statements and 
define financial, operational (including customer service and O&M), as well as short-, medium-, 
and long-term capital investment performance baselines and targets. 
 
47.  A financial assessment of the Project was undertaken. As with many RE projects, the 
capital investment costs per capita of $1,425 per household are high.  The average incremental 
operating costs per kWh of consumption of Nu2.57 are also high.  However, the proposed 
weighted average tariff level of Nu0.73 per kWh that will be charged is low. Thus, based on 
projected revenues and costs, the net cash flow of the Project and the financial internal rate of 
return is negative. The balance of the financial costs will be subsidized thru cross-subsidies 
from HV and MV consumers, and if necessary from income from BPC's transmission activities, 
which presently account for over 67% of BPC's total profit margin.  A summary of the financial 
assessment is in Appendix 3.

13
C.  Economic Aspects 
 
48.  The primary use of electricity by rural residential consumers is for household use. A few 
households have small stores, and some electricity is used to operate equipment in small 
workshops.  The  economic  benefits  of  electricity  consumption  for  these  consumers  are 
evaluated on the basis of (i) the alternative economic costs of other energy sources such as 
kerosene lighting or wood fuel for cooking that will be displaced by using electricity; and (ii) the 
value of additional or induced energy consumption at the estimated average willingness to pay 
for electricity based on a weighted average of the alternative costs of providing similar energy-
related  services  and  the  current  electricity  tariff.  For  this  Project,  the  average  displaced 
kerosene consumption is about 6.2 liters per house per month, which is equivalent to 2.4 kWh of 
electricity (in terms of lumens).  Average electricity consumption in rural Bhutan is relatively high 
at 90.5 kWh per month, due to the low average tariff of only Nu0.71/kWh, thus most electricity 
used  is  induced  additional  energy.  The  weighted  average  economic  value  of  residential 
electricity consumption si estimated to be Nu9.1/kWh in this model12 (or $0.19/kWh). This 
includes an average increase in household income estimated to be about Nu78 per month, or 
about 1% of overall average household income13. It also includes improved health standards due 
to a cleaner environment without kerosene lamps, with less cooking over smoky cooking fires in 
case of houses with electric cooking appliances, and better preservation of food for houses with 
refrigerators. Health benefits are estimated to be an average of about  Nu37 per month per 
household, based on lower costs of medical care required, and reduced number of sick days. 
Appendix 3 provides a more detailed description of the economic evaluation of these benefits. 
 
49.  By 2007, when the Project is fully completed, it will serve an estimated 8,000 rural 
households with a population of about 50,000. This number corresponds to an increase of about 
20% in the total number of consumers served by BPC. It represents an 8% increase in the total 
proportion of the national population with electricity supply, from the current 35% to about 43%. 
The estimated capital cost of the Project is $12.1 million total for distribution at 33 kV and lower, 
including  consumer  connection  costs  and  physical  contingencies.  This  corresponds  to  an 
average cost of $1,425 per household served. The economic evaluation of the RE project is 
based on the average unit benefits and capital costs described above,14 average sales of 90.5 
kWh per month per household, an average cost for bulk power supply of Nu1.38 /kWh based on 
the  current  tariff  and  opportunity  cost  for  bulk  power  exports  to  India,  less  the  cost  of 
transmission wheeling for power exports, plus allowances for domestic transmission costs and 
transmission and distribution losses. Based on these assumptions, the economic internal rate of 
return is conservatively estimated at 12.7% for the base case. Data regarding other benefits 
such as increased useful hours for leisure or housekeeping in the evenings, improved access to

D.  Environmental Aspects 
 
51.  The project is categorized as a “B” Project in accordance with ADB’s environmental 
impact assessment (EIA). The Project, which includes only distribution lines and pole-mounted 
transformers,  is  also  subject  to  Bhutan’s  Environmental  Assessment  Act  2000.    An  Initial 
Environmental  Examination  (IEE)  was  prepared  (Appendix  14)  to  provide  adequate 
environmental assessment.  Based on the IEE, the following issues were raised and addressed. 
(i) The environmental impacts associated with the Project will not be significant (because it will 
not change the land use below the distribution lines and the line alignments will, to the extent 
possible, be located along or close to existing roads or tracks).  However, some stretches of the 
distribution line will pass through forestlands.  Distribution lines that pass through medium and 
dense forestlands will be minimized.  For the most part, distribution lines will pass through 
forestlands with sparse vegetation coverage so that environmental impacts from tree cutting will 
not be significant.  In any case, construction work will be undertaken only after approval for 
forest clearance is obtained from Department of Forestry Services (DOF) and land clearing will 
be limited only to the area granted the clearance. (ii) A stretch of distribution line in Punakha will 
enter the buffer zone and multiple-use zone of Jigme Dorji National Park. However, it will not 
create a significant impact because only about 5 km of the line will enter these zones, and these 
areas are mostly agricultural lands and have no ecological significance. Construction works in 
these  areas  will  be  undertaken  only  after  DOF  approval  is  obtained.    Further,  during 
construction, there will be ongoing consultation with the park management officers. (iii) The 
environmental impacts associated with the construction period will be minor.  In most cases the 
construction  materials  and  equipment  will  be  manually  transported  from  the  nearest  road. 
Because land clearing in locations with steep slope gradients may trigger erosion problems, 
planting grass to provide ground cover will be done simultaneously during the construction work 
or immediately after construction is completed. Adequate ground cover will avoid pole damage 
due to landslides. All poles will be located with adequate distance from water bodies. (iv) The 
operations stage will not create any environmental impact. However, routine line maintenance 
involving trimming of bushes or other vegetation under the lines, particularly in the forest areas, 
will be done in such a way that it will not to affect the forest ecosystem.  Routine maintenance 
for the pole-mounted transformers will generate only a small amount of waste oil (about 0.5 
liters per year based on previous experience), which is reused for lubrication. Further, the waste 
oil will not contain polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs) as BPC only uses PCB-free transformers 
for new construction. (v) BPC will ensure that all construction works under the Project will be 
undertaken only after the environmental clearance from the National Environment Commission 
(NEC) is obtained 
 
52.  Overall environmental impacts are deemed to be minor. The Project will not involve the 
accelerated use of scarce resources; neither will it favor the use of scarce resources to satisfy 
short-term over long-term socioeconomic needs. The project will contribute to more efficient use 
of resources by improving the efficiency of energy use by rural households and reducing the 
consumption of fuelwood and air-polluting kerosene. The IEE also found that the project will 
have negligible effects on the ecology of the Project area and will have a significantly positive 
overall effect on the socioeconomic well-being of the rural population that are beneficiaries of 
the Project.  An environmental management and monitoring plan has been prepared.  During 
construction, regular inspections will be conducted, particularly during the rainy season, to 
ensure that contractors are complying with all clauses in the contract documentation specifying 
mitigation measures and mechanisms for environmental protection (revegetation and provision 
of adequate ground cover). On these basis, an EIA is not necessary.

E.  Risks 
 
  1.    Technical and Institutional 
 
53.     Technical  risks  are  minimal  during  Project  implementation  given  that  BPC  (and 
previously DOP) has already successfully implemented two ADB-financed RE loans. In addition, 
BPC has worked closely with the TA consultants to prepare the technical design, procurement 
packages, bidding documents, and project implementation schedule.  Also, implementation 
consultants  will  assist  BPC  on  procurement.    However,  given  BPC's  limited  capacity  and 
experience to date as a corporate organization, there are institutional risks in terms of effective 
and efficient operational management and sustainability of project assets. BPC is only a year 
old and has yet to fully encompass its overall responsibilities to ensure efficient customer 
service, service delivery, and O&M of assets. To address this, BPC will prepare an overall 
corporate strategy and business plan that includes an appropriate O&M policy and action plan, 
an  asset  replacement  policy  and  action  plan,  strategy,  justified  budgets  and  appropriately 
defined performance indicators for both, for submission to ADB for review within 12 months of 
loan effectiveness. 
 
  2.  Financial and Economic 
 
54.  Cost estimates show the Project to be economically feasible.  Financially, there are 
significant cross-subsidies in the sector.  To ensure that these cross-subsidies are well targeted, 
BEA will develop a strategy and time-bound action plan to rationalize and target cross-subsidies 
to ensure their financial sustainability.  Rationalizing and properly targeting the cross-subsidy 
will ensure the most efficient use of the Government’s resources to support national social and 
economic development goals.  Further, BEA will review BPC’s weighted average tariff earned 
and its tariff structure to define a reasonable rate of return for BPC.  Defining a reasonable rate 
of return on assets or equity will be critical to ensuring the medium- to long-term financial 
sustainability of BPC, and enable it to effectively self-finance service expansion and provide the 
Government with a return on its substantial investment in the sector.  
 
3.  Social and Environmental 
 
55.  The  main  social  risk  is  to  ensure  that  the  Project  actually  serves  its  intended 
beneficiaries, its design has included a socioeconomic impact evaluation of RE in Bhutan.  The 
results serve as the basis for selecting districts and subdistricts for electrification to ensure that 
the intended beneficiaries are reached.  With regard to environmental issues, the Project will 
enter only the periphery, i.e. multipurpose use and buffer zones of protected areas and will not 
be implemented in their core zones.  To minimize the environmental risk, an IEE was conducted 
to ensure that there are no negative environmental impacts in sensitive areas.  Substantive 
public consultations were carried out during the preparation of the Project and the IEE, including 
focus group discussions and individual interviews at the household, village, subdistrict and 
district levels by ADB and the PPTA consultants.

6.  The average economic cost of power supply from the Project will be about Nu8.6/kWh

average  cost  of  about  $0.31/kWh.  Details  of  this  calculation  are  shown  in  Supplementary

extension of the distribution grid.  Grid extensions in Bhutan would be more costly than diesel 
when the average cost of a grid extension exceeds $2,750 per household (the switching value). 
However, at this cost level neither option would be considered economically viable since for 
both the average costs would exceed the average economic benefits of supply to consumers.  
(ii) A few demonstration projects for household solar photovoltaic (PV) systems in rural areas 
have also been developed in Bhutan (1,300 units in total).  While these PV systems were given 
free, their maintenance and sustainability continue to be problematic to date. Average capital 
costs are about $800 for a basic low-capacity household system (3 compact florescent lamps 
lights of 15 watts each), and the average economic cost of electricity used are about $1.80/kWh.  
While this may be considered for minimum lighting requirements in remote rural areas, it is too 
costly for larger scale applications. (iii) A few off-grid minihydro projects of less than 1000 kW 
have  also  been  developed  in  Bhutan,  and  have  been  studied  and  proposed  for  external 
financing on a grant basis.  However, they are relatively costly, with an average cost of about 
$5,000 per household served for power plant capacity and associated distribution. This is much 
more costly than extension of the integrated distribution grid as planned under the Project.  
Furthermore, good off-grid minihydro projects are only available in a few locations.

around 66 years for both men and women. The proportion of the population with 
access to safe drinking water increased from 45% in 1996 to 78% in 2000, while 
the population covered by some form of health care is 90%. Overall, the literacy 
rate is 46%.  Nearly a quarter of the Project’s beneficiaries are from households 
falling below the higher poverty line.  Some 18% are households falling below the 
lower poverty line set at Nu612 per capita per month and 28% are considered 
vulnerable (i.e., 15% above the higher poverty line of Nu748 per capita per 
month).    
 
4.  The general environmental conditions along the alignment of the distribution lines are as 
follows:   
 
(i)  Chhukha. Lines will run mainly along the highway. Coniferous and broadleaf 
forests are the main vegetated areas through which the lines pass.  The right-of-
way (ROW) will require clearance of 0.4 km of dense forest, 11.4 km of mild 
forest, and 5 km of sparse forest. The rest of the alignment passes through 
pasture and bush-land, dryland agriculture, and orchards. Topographically, the 
lines cross mostly easy terrain, passing over 17 km of rough but accessible 
terrain, 1 km of steep and rocky terrain, and over 5 km of steep forested terrain. 
The lines will not go through areas with slopes greater than 45 degrees.  
 
(ii)  Samtse. The ROW will go through 5 km of mild forest, 16 km of sparse forest, 3 
km of pasture, and the remainder through residential and agricultural land. The

D.Screening of Potential Environmental Impacts and Mitigation Measures 
 
5.  The screening of potential impacts shows no significant environmental impact due to 
citing of these distribution lines and pole-mounted transformers substations, because use of the 
land below the transmission lines will not change. The alignment will also as much as possible 
be located along, or close to, existing roads or tracks. However, some stretch of distribution 
lines that pass through forest area will require land clearing. The distribution lines that pass 
through forest area will only be executed after the Department of Forest Services (DOF) grants 
forest clearances. Land clearing will be limited only to the area covered by the clearance. A 
stretch of distribution line in Punakha will enter the buffer zone and multiple-use zone of the 
Jigme Dorji National Park.  However, that stretch will not create a significant impact because 
only about 5 km of the line will enter these zones and these areas are mostly agricultural lands 
and  have  no  ecological  significance.  The  construction  works  involving  these  areas  will  be 
undertaken only after the DOF’s approval is obtained.  Further, during construction, continued 
consultation with the park management officers will be undertaken. 
 
6.  The environmental impacts associated with the construction period will be minor.  In 
most cases, the construction materials and equipment will be manually transported from the 
nearest road. Only land clearing at locations with steep slope gradients may trigger erosion

problems.  Planting  of  grass  to  provide  ground  cover  will  be  done  simultaneously  during 
construction or immediately after the completion of construction. Ground cover will also prevent 
pole damage due to landslides. All poles will be located at adequate distance from water bodies.  
The  operations  stage  will  not  create  any  environmental  impact.  However,  routine  line 
maintenance involving trimming of bushes or other vegetation under the lines, particularly in the

E.  INSTITUTIONAL  REQUIREMENTS  AND  ENVIRONMENTAL  MANAGEMENT 
MONITORING PLAN 
 
7.  An  environmental  management  and  monitoring  plan  was  prepared  for  the  Project.  
During construction, regular inspection will be conducted, particularly during the rainy season, to 
ensure that contractors are complying with all clauses in the contract documents specifying 
mitigation  measures  and  mechanisms  for  environmental  protection.    An  environmental 
clearance for constructing each distribution line is required from the National Environment 
Commission. Continued consultation with park management is necessary before getting forest 
clearance or during project implementation in Punakha. Furthermore, forest clearances for all 
the work involving forestlands will be obtained before construction work in those areas begins. 
BPC  must  implement  all  conditions  of  the  environmental  clearance  and  forest  clearances. 
Overall implementation of environmental mitigation measures will also be the responsibility of 
BPC.  Therefore,  BPC’s  environmental  staff  who  will  be  hired  in  October  2003  and  field 
engineers  will  monitor  implementation  of  the  mitigation  measures  as  well  as  of  the 
environmental requirements of the environmental and forest clearances.  
 
8.  The RE process is one of consultation beginning with dialogue with heads of blocks. The 
heads,  in  consultation  with  their  communities,  will  identify  and  list  the  households  to  be 
connected and submit that list to the Department of Energy (DOE) as part of the primary initial 
selection process.  Stakeholder participation in TA 38253 has included introductory meetings 
with key agencies and the blocks in the project areas.  Consultation with beneficiaries and 
directly affected people has also been undertaken through the social/poverty and environmental 
assessment process.   
 
F. Findings and Recommendations 
 
9.  The IEE found that the Project will have negligible effects on the ecology of the project 
area and will have a significantly positive overall effect on the socioeconomic well-being of the 
rural population that are beneficiaries of the Project. Benefits from this Project far outweigh the 
negative  impact  when  mitigation  measures  are  adopted.  The  IEE  is  therefore  considered 
sufficient. 
 
G.  Conclusion 
 
10.  Overall environmental impacts are deemed to be minor. The Project will not involve the 
accelerated use of scarce resources, nor will it favor the use of scarce resources to satisfy
